title: Does criminal misdemeanor disqualify you from filing Chapter 7.
question: I entered a "no contest" plea to a misdemeanor criminal offense in CA. I am in the process of completing my community service hours now and will be done in the next two weeks. I wish to hire an attorney and to file for Chapter 7 Bankruptcy. Does having a criminal misdemeanor disqualify you from filing Chapter 7? Or is this just considered a debt that is not dischargeable. This a Debt / Bankruptcy Chapter 7 question - (not seeing that option to check below). Thank You.
answers: The answer to your question is contained in Section 109 of the bankruptcy code "who can be a debtor." To the best of my knowldege having a criminal misdemeanor does not disqualify you from filing Chapter 7.

If you have been convicted of a financial related crime, that may have an impact upon your bankruptcy case. Other than that your criminal record should not affect your Chapter 7 filing, but you need to make sure you qualify. Any court ordered repayments, fines, or restitution from the misdemeanor cannot be discharged in the bankruptcy. I recommend consulting with an experience bankruptcy attorney to help guide you through the proper steps to take and explain the process. Contact me at 562-984-2074 or gdatta@dattalawgroup.com for more guidance and clarification regarding your question.
Your Criminal records should not affect your Chapter 7 filing. But you need to make sure you qualify. Also those debts will not be discharged.

You can file bankruptcy. Having a criminal record does not matter.

However, court ordered repayments and or restitution is Not dischargeable.

The bankruptcy codes' qualifications to file bankruptcy doe not include an exception for someone committing a criminal offense!

Second, that debt is not dischargeable for a criminal fine payable to a governmental unit if not for actual pecuniary loss pursuant to 11 USC 523(a)(7)! Any debt owed to the person whom the crime was committed against may also have a non dischargeable type debt.

Finally, you need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines as I quoted you above , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

If you have been convicted of a financial related crime, that may have an impact upon your bankruptcy case. If it is for something else, it should really have no bearing. You will still be responsible for your restitution and fines. Be sure to communicate with experienced bankruptcy counsel in your area to completely review your finances with you and determine whether a bankruptcy is the best thing for you.
Generally a criminal offense doesn't disqualify you from filling bankruptcy. However there are many issues that need to discussed. Feel free to contact my office to discuss.
This will not disqualify you but it is in the information you will provide to the bankruptcy attorney but any fines from the misdemeanor cannot be removed in the bankruptcy.
Generally, a misdemeanor conviction should not disqualify you from filing for bankruptcy. However, you should consult a bankruptcy attorney to be sure.
